Kent Beck wrote:

> However, as Erich is at pains to explain to me frequently, that is not the context in which we are writing JUnit. We need to balance the need for flexibility of extension with the need for flexibility of design evolution. Revealing all the details of our implementation means we can't change anything. And so we are left, as you said, revealing only as much as we are certain will be useful.

I basically agree with that. Protected methods are fine, as long as 
you're reasonably confident they're right and you're willing to maintain 
them in the future.

> This leaves me unsettled. I know that my frameworks aren't as useful as they could be, but I also know that I would regret opening them up completely. I don't see how to strike a better balance than we strike with JUnit, though, so I'll live with it.

I think extreme programming/agile development offers a path out of this 
conundrum. Instead of looking for one big bang release that then stands 
untouched for a few years, look to more incremental releases (like in 
the earlier days of JUnit). Two week release cycles give you plenty of 
opportunities to open up the framework to extension as people actually 
need and request the extension. I've found by experience that I tend to 
be very bad at predicting what actually will be needed, even by myself. 
Therefore the longer I can delay the decision, the more likely it is 
that the eventual decision will be correct.

Of course, at least half of this is stuff I learned first from your 
book. :-)
